title: Analysis Walkthrough Example
text:
Code
impeach <- readRDS("impeach.rds")



TABLES
Displaying how many members in the dataset favor impeachment vs. not


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment) %>% 
  summarise(for_impeach_count = n())


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  for_impeachment for_impeach_count
  <chr>                       <int>
1 NO                             26
2 YES                           209


Now using grouping to now break down the Democratic House members by TWO measures: those who are for or against impeachment (as you did above)….and then districts above/below national GDP.


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment, gdp_above_national) %>% 
  summarise(for_impeach_count = n())


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'for_impeachment'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 4 × 3
# Groups:   for_impeachment [2]
  for_impeachment gdp_above_national for_impeach_count
  <chr>           <chr>                          <int>
1 NO              ABOVE                              7
2 NO              BELOW                             19
3 YES             ABOVE                            126
4 YES             BELOW                             83


Now nstead of GDP, grouping by whether the district is above or below the national average for the percentage of college graduates.


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment, pct_bachelors_compared_to_national) %>% 
  summarise(impeach_count = n())


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'for_impeachment'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 4 × 3
# Groups:   for_impeachment [2]
  for_impeachment pct_bachelors_compared_to_national impeach_count
  <chr>           <chr>                                      <int>
1 NO              ABOVE                                          7
2 NO              BELOW                                         19
3 YES             ABOVE                                        128
4 YES             BELOW                                         81


Here I’m summarizing by the mean percentage of college grads for districts that are Yes for impeachment vs. No. 


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment) %>% 
  summarise(impeach_count = n(), 
            mean_pct_grad = mean(pct_bachelors, na.rm = TRUE))


# A tibble: 2 × 3
  for_impeachment impeach_count mean_pct_grad
  <chr>                   <int>         <dbl>
1 NO                         26          27.7
2 YES                       209          33.7


Now showing the percentage of the vote that Donald Trump received for districts that are Yes for impeachment vs. No. 


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment) %>% 
  summarise(impeach_count = n(), 
            mean_trump_pct = mean(trump_percent, na.rm = TRUE))


# A tibble: 2 × 3
  for_impeachment impeach_count mean_trump_pct
  <chr>                   <int>          <dbl>
1 NO                         26           43.8
2 YES                       209           32.0


Filtering out only the members who are a yes for impeachment. Also showing how many of those who voted yes won their 2018 election by less than 5 percentage points (margin_flag_2018) vs. more?


Code
  impeach %>% 
  filter(for_impeachment == "YES") %>% 
  group_by(margin_flag_2018) %>% 
  summarise(yes_impeach_count = n())


# A tibble: 2 × 2
  margin_flag_2018   yes_impeach_count
  <chr>                          <int>
1 5_points_or_less                  17
2 more_than_5_points               192


Testing how median income of a district, and if it is above or below the national average, effects whether or not a House member voted yes or no by taking the mean of median income above or below the average.


Code
impeach %>% 
  group_by(for_impeachment, median_age_compared_to_national) %>% 
  summarise(impeach_count = n(), 
            mean_income = mean(median_income, na.rm = TRUE))


`summarise()` has grouped output by 'for_impeachment'. You can override using
the `.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 4 × 4
# Groups:   for_impeachment [2]
  for_impeachment median_age_compared_to_national impeach_count mean_income
  <chr>           <chr>                                   <int>       <dbl>
1 NO              ABOVE                                      13      59110.
2 NO              BELOW                                      13      48313.
3 YES             ABOVE                                      96      68903.
4 YES             BELOW                                     113      56333.


Using the mutate() function to create two new columns: one that extracts the year from date_announced, and a second that extracts the month.


Code
impeach %>%
  mutate(year = year(date_announced),
         month = month(date_announced))


# A tibble: 235 × 28
   for_impeachm…¹ last_…² first…³ middl…⁴ party state distr…⁵ date_ann…⁶ margi…⁷
   <chr>          <chr>   <chr>   <chr>   <chr> <chr> <chr>   <date>     <chr>  
 1 YES            Adams   Alma    <NA>    D     NC    12      2019-05-31 more_t…
 2 YES            Aguilar Pete    <NA>    D     CA    31      2019-08-01 more_t…
 3 NO             Allred  Colin   <NA>    D     TX    32      NA         more_t…
 4 YES            Axne    Cynthia <NA>    D     IA    3       2019-09-24 5_poin…
 5 YES            Barrag… Nanette <NA>    D     CA    44      2019-06-01 more_t…
 6 YES            Bass    Karen   <NA>    D     CA    37      2019-09-24 more_t…
 7 YES            Beatty  Joyce   <NA>    D     OH    3       2019-05-31 more_t…
 8 YES            Bera    Ami     <NA>    D     CA    7       2019-09-24 more_t…
 9 YES            Beyer   Donald  <NA>    D     VA    8       2019-05-01 more_t…
10 YES            Bishop  Sanford D.      D     GA    2       2019-09-24 more_t…
# … with 225 more rows, 19 more variables: flip_2018 <chr>, house_dist <chr>,
#   keyrace_rating <chr>, median_income <dbl>,
#   median_income_compared_to_national <chr>, median_age <dbl>,
#   median_age_compared_to_national <chr>, pct_nonwhite <dbl>,
#   pct_nonwhite_compared_to_national <chr>, pct_bachelors <dbl>,
#   pct_bachelors_compared_to_national <chr>, rural_pop_above20pct <chr>,
#   gdp_above_national <chr>, clinton_percent <dbl>, trump_percent <dbl>, …


Using the new columns to then use grouping to count up how many House Democrats during each month announced their support of impeachment.


Code
impeach %>%
  mutate(year = year(date_announced),
         month = month(date_announced)) %>% 
  filter(for_impeachment == "YES") %>%
  group_by(month) %>%
  summarise(impeach_count = n())


# A tibble: 9 × 2
  month impeach_count
  <dbl>         <int>
1     1             3
2     4             7
3     5            39
4     6            27
5     7            33
6     8            18
7     9            76
8    11             2
9    12             4

title: Samiha Farooqi
text: Hi, I’m Samiha and I’m currently a history and data science student at the George Washington University

title: Portfolio
text: While at MediaFileDC, a student run online news source, I spoke to various academics and experts while covering stories on the international beat. My stories ranged from the Western media coverage of Afghan women, to the media scrutiny Meghan Markle faced from the UK press.

title: More Stuff About Me
text:
About this site
Here is some new stuff!

1 + 1 

[1] 2

title: Portfolio
text:
GW Hatchet Articles
At The Hatchet, I covered two stories on campus involving the implentation of GW’s u-pass program, and the student and university responses to an assault, interviewing several students in the process.
